turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: They'd never talk in front of me. They'd walk away up the beach. Nervous about something.

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: Friend of Gruner. Just went along for the party.

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: It was a good job. Not many ways for a foreigner to make money here. Ryuji hires me to organize business meetings...take care of things.

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: This boat doesn't go anywhere. Just toots around the Inland Sea.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Must be a pick-up, a rendezvous.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: He plays it all the time.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: We figure out if it's in here.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Why don't you get us some food. This may take some time.

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: That must be him. Water taxi.

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: Too late, they won't come back out till morning.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Where would you go to sell a chip?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: If Gruner led us away, Who'd he lead us away from?

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: Dieter's gone to shoot a still job. Hong Kong.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Wait a minute! How'd you know Dieter was coming here?

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: He's a client of mine! What's the matter. You can't suspect Dieter. He's a famous photographer. He makes millions.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Maybe I'm wrong. Then GRUNER won't be here.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I said just relax. I'm in full control.

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: That's not this direction. It's back the other way.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Maybe they're expecting Gruner. I'm gonna be him.

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: He's Dutch. You can't even speak Dutch.

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: Yes. No. I'm...okay. They can't do this. They can't hold us here.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Looks like they can. What did they do?

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: They'll listen to what we say in here.

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: What? Oh, about Dieter, Yes. It was him. Gruner works for him.

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: You can say that again. What do we do?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: They can hold us here forever. Nobody knows about us.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I'm sorry I got you into this.

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: Don't blame yourself, I didn't have to come along.

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: I encouraged you to come here. My fault as much as yours.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I was...crazy...desperate. I took it out on you. I didn't mean it. I know what she sees in you. You're kind and you're brave. If I ever get out of you, I'll be glad to call you my friend.

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: I've never met anyone like you.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Uh...wonderful. I know I'm strange, but in my own way, I love you

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: Why not, what are you going to do?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You son of a bitch! You conned me!

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Who are you? Who do you work for?

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: Doesn't matter. I'm on your side.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I knew it. I told him.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Do what? I don't know. I'm no good at this.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: It wasn't me. It was him.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: He told me what to do.

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: But you did it. It was you.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: It was me. He just told me how...I wish he could tell me now.

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: If he was able, what would he say.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Like Al says..."Under stress, the human body is capable of impossible feats.

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: I told you, I work for him.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: We're not moving fast enough for him.

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: He should do it in person ...I mean ex person.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: It keeps me busy. Everybody always wants something.

turns.speaker: RYUJI
turns.text: What could you find in this place?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Could have been drunk a little sooner, but excellent...good character...What is it?

turns.speaker: RYUJI
turns.text: I can't. He didn't do anything. Thanks to you.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Why are you on to him?

turns.speaker: RYUJI
turns.text: We've had thefts of our new stuff ...GRUNER deals in this... A big deal is going down now. I went to see if GRUNER had anything to sell. But he didn't make any moves...And when you arrived, he backed off.

turns.speaker: RYUJI
turns.text: Someone is selling. You followed us. If it's not him, it must be you. If it's not you, it must be him... You scared him off.

turns.speaker: RECEPTIONIST.
turns.text: I'm sorry. We're running behind. So many applicants...so few jobs... If you'll just have a seat.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I have a seat. I've had it since nine.

turns.speaker: RECEPTIONIST.
turns.text: ...Mr. Athol will be with you as soon as possible. Will you be able to wait?

turns.speaker: RECEPTIONIST.
turns.text: Water fountain's through that door, down the hall.

turns.speaker: LEADER
turns.text: It will be fine. You have another.

turns.speaker: TECH 3
turns.text: I can't get it out. It would take hours.

turns.speaker: LEADER
turns.text: That's alright. Just tear it apart.

turns.speaker: LEADER
turns.text: Leaving, now go to sleep. ...all of you.

turns.speaker: TECH 2
turns.text: What'd he say, how's he know about Al?

turns.speaker: TECH 3
turns.text: Look, nobody knows we did it.

turns.speaker: BARBARA
turns.text: Ms. Laufer gave me a star today.

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: That's great... Little early for cartoons, isn't it?

turns.speaker: BARBARA
turns.text: She was playing with my Pooh doll again...

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: Here we go. Deep breaths, deep breaths.

turns.speaker: BARBARA
turns.text: She was playing with the Pooh doll.

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: Pooh's dusty, sweetheart... he's dusty, and you breathed him in, okay? So what's -- what's happening to you now is... cells called mast cells told your lungs "don't breathe any more of that dust in."  ...and the airways in your lungs are like branches. And when the branches close up, you get an asthmatic attack. And, we give you medicine, and you get better. Huh? Okay? You're better already, aren't you?

turns.speaker: BARBARA
turns.text: Can I go over to Janeane's house?

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: Did you see somebody or did you hear them?

turns.speaker: BARBARA
turns.text: He's into kind of little cars, that...

turns.speaker: BILL ROBERTSON'S VOICE
turns.text: Let me tell you something, Lowell. Look, look, look. You're talking about two agents in a regional office in Louisville. I got the goddamn Unabomber threatening to blow up LAX! I gotta move 45 agents from all over the country into L.A.  Alright? When I get a chance, I'll give it a look...

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: You better take a good look! Because I'm getting two things: pissed off and curious! Now, any of these guys been offered jobs in corporate security after they retire? Either one of those guys have ex-agent pals already in those jobs? Like, for instance, their ex-supervisor, who's already at Brown & Williamson as we fucking speak?

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: Just ran into two of your "geologists." Geologists whose hands aren't all chewed up...?

turns.speaker: BILL ROBERTSON'S VOICE
turns.text: We'll give you a heads up before we launch.

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: Well, are you or are you not, Charlie?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE PHILLIPS
turns.text: You bet we are. And I can't talk to you now.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE PHILLIPS
turns.text: It's drawn from a selectively circulated...

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: Oh, it's real selective... about as hard to get a hold of as the Manhattan phone book.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE PHILLIPS
turns.text: Well, it's authoritative and is overwhelmingly documented.

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: And it's bullshit. And if I'm right, are you going to put the Journal's reputation behind a story that's going to blow up in your face?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE PHILLIPS
turns.text: I'll take a look at what you got. But I'm not moving any deadlines 'cause you say so.

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: These are their leads, their sources. I want you to have your reporters...

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: Have them make their own calls. They'll find that these sources have a different story than the one that's in the dossier...  Push the deadline, Charlie...

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: I want you to get legal onto CORPORATE CONFIDENTIALITY AGREEMENTS. Boundaries of their constraint. Kentucky state law about. I want you to drop everything.

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: What do you mean, what's it do?

turns.speaker: DEBBIE DELUCA
turns.text: What I mean is, like, how does it cut through the confidentiality agreement?

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: Because he has to reveal it in a court of law. It's on record, it's out. It's no secret anymore. So how can they restrain his speech or retaliate? It's out in the world...

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: Oh, we need cops on the street. We don't need them on horses.

turns.speaker: DEBBIE DELUCA
turns.text: I don't know what he was thinking.

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: Oh, for God's sake, what has this guy got, a horse fetish?

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: Get me to New Orleans this afternoon. I'll shoot the fucking thing myself!

turns.speaker: DEBBIE DELUCA
turns.text: Excuse me, Lowell. Sharon's on line 3.

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: Tell her I'll call her back in ten.

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: I can't get out of here til mid- morning. I'll be in tomorrow night...  Listen, could you call a number for me, it's in Mississippi...

turns.speaker: DEBBIE DELUCA
turns.text: Okay. Hold on a second... What is it?

turns.speaker: DEBBIE DELUCA
turns.text: Yeah. Yeah, sure. I'll see if I can find him. Hold on...  Yeah, Don's looking for you...

turns.speaker: DEBBIE DELUCA
turns.text: The sub-heading is, "Brown & Williamson Has a 500-Page Dossier Attacking Chief Critic." It quotes Richard Scruggs calling it "the worst kind of an organized smear campaign against a whistle-blower."

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Can I go to dance tomorrow? I'm better...

turns.speaker: LIANE
turns.text: ...if you are, then I'll take Barbara to soccer and take you to dance after...

turns.speaker: DON HEWITT
turns.text: I heard Wigand's deposition got sealed.

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: Yeah, they argued he was going to reveal the secret formula of "Kools" to the world.  "Sealed" doesn't hurt Scruggs' litigation, and since we're the only ones with the story, I believe we're sitting on an exclusive.

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: "Tortious interference"? Sounds like a disease caught by a radio.

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: Since when has the paragon of investigative journalism allowed lawyers to determine the news content on "60 Minutes"?

turns.speaker: DON HEWITT
turns.text: It's an alternate version. So what if we have an alternate version? And I don't think her being cautious is so damned unreasonable.

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: It's not a rumor. It's a sale.  If Tisch can unload CBS for $81 a share to Westinghouse and then is suddenly threatened with a multibillion-dollar lawsuit from Brown & Williamson, that could screw up the sale, could it not?

turns.speaker: DON HEWITT
turns.text: Are you suggesting that she and Eric are influenced by money?

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: Oh, no, of course they're not influenced by money. They work for free. And you are a Volunteer Executive Producer.

turns.speaker: DON HEWITT
turns.text: CBS does not do that. And, you're questioning our journalistic integrity?!

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: No, I'm questioning your hearing! You hear "reasonable" and "tortious interference." I hear... "Potential Brown & Williamson lawsuit jeopardizing the sale of CBS to Westinghouse." I hear... "Shut the segment down. Cut Wigand loose. Obey orders. And fuck off...!" That's what I hear.

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: I am? You pay me to go get guys like Wigand, to draw him out. To get him to trust us, to get him to go on television. I do. I deliver him. He sits. He talks. He violates his own fucking confidentiality agreement. And he's only the key witness in the biggest public health reform issue, maybe the biggest, most-expensive corporate-malfeasance case in U.S. history. And Jeffrey Wigand, who's out on a limb, does he go on television and tell the truth? Yes. Is it newsworthy? Yes. Are we gonna air it? Of course not. Why? Because he's not telling the truth? No. Because he is telling the truth. That's why we're not going to air it. And the more truth he tells, the worse it gets!

turns.speaker: DON HEWITT
turns.text: You are a fanatic. An anarchist. You know that? If we can't have a whole show, then I want half a show rather than no show. But oh, no, not you. You won't be satisfied unless you're putting the company at risk!

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: C'mon, what are you? And are you a businessman? Or are you a newsman?! Because that happens to be what Mike and I do for a living...

turns.speaker: DON HEWITT
turns.text: So, what are you going to do?

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: Well, what do you think I'm going to do? Quit in protest? I'm not going to do that.

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: No. I'm not going to take "no" for an answer. No.

turns.speaker: DON HEWITT
turns.text: Then what are you going to do?

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: I'm staying right here. Doing my job. Fighting to get my show on the air. You don't like it? Hey, I'll tell you what... fire my ass...

turns.speaker: DON HEWITT
turns.text: End up in a high-profile lawsuit with Lowell, the First Amendment martyr? I don't think so.  Take a look at this... This is a summary of a dossier that's being prepared.

turns.speaker: DON HEWITT
turns.text: What the hell are you doing?

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: What does it look like I'm doing? I'm editing.

turns.speaker: DON HEWITT
turns.text: No, not that. I'm talking about the Associated Press. They got this story that we pulled this interview and they talked to Mike and I. Did you tell them that we were lying?

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: No. I should have. I told them I disagreed with you, Mike and Kluster that this segment is as good as the original. I'm not lying for you. I'm not gonna shut up for you. Not on any of it.

turns.speaker: DON HEWITT
turns.text: Hey! I'm not going to fire you, okay? Take a vacation. Now!

turns.speaker: DON HEWITT
turns.text: The New York Times ran a blow by blow of what we talked about behind closed doors! You fucked us!

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: No, you fucked you! Don't invert stuff! Big Tobacco tried to smear Wigand; you bought it. The Wall Street Journal, here, not exactly a bastion of anti-capitalist sentiment, refutes Big Tobacco's smear campaign as the lowest form of character assassination! And now, even now, when every word of what Wigand has said on our show is printed, the entire deposition of his testimony in a court of law in the State of Mississippi, the cat totally out of the bag, you're still standing here debating! Don, what the hell else... do you need?

turns.speaker: ERIC KLUSTER
turns.text: There has been so much soul searching about this Wigand, I've decided we should cut an alternate version of the show without his interview.

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: So, what happened to Ms. Caperelli's checking with outside counsel first, all that crap?

turns.speaker: ERIC KLUSTER
turns.text: That's happening. And, hopefully we won't have to use the alternate, but we should have it in the can.

turns.speaker: ERIC KLUSTER
turns.text: We're doing this with or without you, Lowell. If you like, I can assign another producer to edit your show...

turns.speaker: ERIC KLUSTER
turns.text: So, now, if you'll excuse me, gentlemen, Mr. Rather's been complaining about his chair again.  As they start to leave...

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: I'm not implying. I'm quoting. More vested interests...  "Persons Who Will Profit From This Merger...  Ms. Helen Caperelli, General Counsel of CBS News, 3.9 million. Mr. Eric Kluster, President of CBS News, 1.4 million..."

turns.speaker: FBI AGENT #2
turns.text: Did you handle the round, Mr. Wigand?

turns.speaker: FBI AGENT #2
turns.text: Yes, sir. What caliber is your gun?

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: What does that have to do with the price of tea in China?

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: You think I put that bullet in the mailbox myself...?

turns.speaker: FBI AGENT #2
turns.text: If we could take a look, Mr. Wigand...

turns.speaker: FBI AGENT #2
turns.text: That bullet was for a .38 caliber. Do you own a .38?

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: Yes, I do. A .38 Target Master. In my gun safe downstairs. A .45 Gold Cup. A .22 target pistol. So what?

turns.speaker: FBI AGENT #2
turns.text: Do you have a history of emotional problems, Mr. Wigand?

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: Yes. Yes, I do.  Yes, I get extremely emotional when assholes put bullets in my mailbox...!

turns.speaker: WIGAND
turns.text: You can't take that... It's personal property...!

turns.speaker: FBI AGENT #2
turns.text: We have a search warrant, Mr. Wigand. There's been a death threat.

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: Oh, Bill... Main Justice is investigating a major New York bank. Laundering narco dollars out of their Mexico City branch. You want it for the Evening News?

turns.speaker: FELLING
turns.text: What about you, you got a crew already?

turns.speaker: HELEN CAPERELLI
turns.text: Shall I send for coffee? Sorry I'm late.

turns.speaker: HELEN CAPERELLI
turns.text: If this holds up, and it very well may not, Mike... but, if it did. And we aired this segment? And CBS was sued by Brown & Williamson? I think we could be at grave risk.

turns.speaker: HELEN CAPERELLI
turns.text: Well, at the end of the day... because of your segment... the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Company... could own CBS.

turns.speaker: HELEN CAPERELLI
turns.text: I'm told unusual promises were made to Wigand.

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: No, only that we would hold the story until it was safe for him...

turns.speaker: HELEN CAPERELLI
turns.text: And, I'm told there are questions as to our "star witness'" veracity.

turns.speaker: LOWELL
turns.text: His "veracity" was good enough for the State of Mississippi.

turns.speaker: HELEN CAPERELLI
turns.text: Our standards have to be higher than anyone else's, because we are the standard... for everyone else...
